title: Zeke Bella
text:
John "Zeke" Bella (August 22, 1930 – November 17, 2013) was a <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> <a href="outfielder">outfielder</a> who appeared in 52 total games for the <a href="New%20York%20Yankees">New York Yankees</a> in and the <a href="Kansas%20City%20Athletics">Kansas City Athletics</a> in .
Early life.
Zeke Bella was born August 22, 1930, in <a href="Greenwich%2C%20Connecticut">Greenwich, Connecticut</a>. Bella graduated from Greenwich High School in 1947 where he was called "[a] superlative athlete"; playing both football and baseball.
MLB career.
Bella began his professional career with the Class C <a href="Amsterdam%20Rugmakers">Amsterdam Rugmakers</a>, a Yankees' <a href="farm%20system">fram team</a>, in 1951. He was among the relatively few position players who batted right-handed and threw left-handed, and was listed as tall and .
After two years' service in the <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a> during the <a href="Korean%20War">Korean War</a>, he spent 1954 and 1955 with the Class A <a href="Binghamton%20Triplets">Binghamton Triplets</a>, then played from 1956 to 1958 with the <a href="Triple-A%20%28baseball%29">Triple-A</a> <a href="Denver%20Bears">Denver Bears</a>, the Yankees' top minor league affiliate.
Bella began his major league career on September 11, 1957, with the Yankees, playing in five <a href="games%20played">games</a> and garnering one <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">hit</a> in ten <a href="at%20bats">at bats</a> during what would be his only appearances with the Bombers. After spending 1958 with the Bears, he was traded to Kansas City for veteran <a href="relief%20pitcher">relief pitcher</a> <a href="Murry%20Dickson">Murry Dickson</a> on August 22. Bella then played in 47 games for Athletics in 1959. He hit his lone major-league <a href="home%20run">home run</a> on August 13, a <a href="run%20%28baseball%29">two-run</a> shot off <a href="Jack%20Harshman">Jack Harshman</a> of the <a href="Cleveland%20Indians">Cleveland Indians</a>. He retired from baseball after the 1960 minor-league season.
Over his 52-game <a href="MLB">MLB</a> career, Bella had 18 hits in 92 at-bats, with a .196 <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batting average</a>.
Awards and honors.
Bella was inducted into the Greenwich High School Sports Hall of Fame in 2013.
Death.
Zeke Bella died on November 17, 2013, from complications due to a stroke, and the injuries received from a fall it induced; Bella was aged 83 years when he succumbed.
